Hebrew.rule:
The Rules of Shewa
 2. Vocal schewa cannot proceed a guttural with a reduced vowel.  The first vocal
    schewa converts to the short vowel that corresponds to the reduced vowel it
    proceeds.  חֲלוֹם plus בְּ becomes בַּחֲלוֹם
    Exception: In אֱלֹהִים  the shortened vowel under א  is removed.  Thus אֱלֹהִים plus לְ becomes לֵאלֹהִים

Definite Article
 * Definite Article is הַ plus a Dagesh Forte in the first consonant of the noun

Definite Article
 * When the first consonant is a בגדכפת consonant the Dagesh Lene in the בגדכפת becomes a Dagesh Forte

Definite Article
 * When first consontant is a guttural, Dagesh Forte is rejected

Definite Article
   * When the first consonant is א or ע or ר the Patach lengthens to a Qamets, הָ

Definite Article
   * When the first consonant is ה or ח the Dagesh Forte is dropped.  This is
     referred to as "virtual doubling"

Definite Article
   * Before nouns that begin with an unaccented עָ or הָ or חָ (last can also be
     accented), the definite article becomes Seghol הֶ

Definite Article
 * A few words change their initial vowel to Qamets, e.g. אֶרֶצ becomes הָאָרֶצ

Additional meanings of the definite article:
 * Demonstrative (this/that): אנכי מצוך היום - I am commanding you the[this] day

Additional meanings of the definite article:
 * Vocative, indicating direct address: ויקרא לאמר המלך - And he called saying the[O] king

Additional meanings of the definite article:
 * Superlative with an adjective: הטוב והישׁר - the good[best] and the upright[most upright]

Additional meanings of the definite article:
 * Possessive pronoun: ולקח דוד הכנור - And David took the[his] harp

Conjunction ו (and, but, also, even)
 * Most frequently spelled וְ

Conjunction ו (and, but, also, even)
 * Becomes Shureq וּ 
   * before ב, מ, פ (bump rule), ב פ loose Dagesh lene in this case בּיִת becomes וּבַיִת 
   * before a vocal Shewa נְעָרִים becomes וּנְעָרִים

Conjunction ו (and, but, also, even)
 * Before Hateph vowel, conjunction takes the corresponding short vowel אֲנָשׁים becomes וַאֲנָשׁים  
   * Exception, does not apply to אלהים

Conjunction ו (and, but, also, even)
 * May be spelled with Qamets before monosyllabic words or words with initial accent צֹאן becomes וָצֹאן

Inseparable prepositions
* Before most consonants will appear with a vocal Shewa ּּּבְשָדֶה

Inseparable prepositions
* Before a Hateph vowel will take the corresponding short vowel כַּאֲנָשִׁים

Inseparable prepositions
* Before a vocal Shewa will take a Hireq לִנְבִיאִים

Inseparable prepositions
* When combined with a definite article replaces the ה and takes its vowel ּבַשָּׂדֶה

The preposition מִן
 * Frequently is joined to its object via a Maqqef (-)

The preposition מִן
 * Can occur as an inseparable preposition, in which case the first consontant of
   the noun to which it is prefixed usually takes a dagesh forte: מִמֶּלֶך

The preposition מִן
   * When the first letter is a begadkephat letter with a dagesh lene, the dagesh
     lene becomes a dagesh forte
   * When the first letter is a gutteral, the hireq under מ lengthens to a tsere
     e.g. מֵאִישׁ
   * When the first letter is ח there is not usually vowel lengthening.

The preposition מִן
   * (Beyond from) Comparative use: applied to adjective to make it comparative
     e.g. טוֹבָה חָכְמָה מִזָּהָב wisdom is better than gold
   * (Beyond from) Superlative use: used with כּל to express superlative
     e.g. עָרוּם מִכֹּל חַיַּת הַשָּׂדֶה the most clever living thing of the field
   * (Beyond from) Partitive use: Can mean a part of something: מֵהָאֲנָשִׁים some of the men

Preposition plus פנה (face)
   * before, in the precense of: לִפְנֵי

Preposition plus פנה (face)
   * away from, out from, from before, on account of: מִפְּנֵי and מִלִּפְנֵי

Preposition plus פנה (face)
   * in the face, in the sight of, before, up against, opposite to: עַלֿֿ-פְּנֵי

Preposition plus דבר
   * on account of עַל-דְּבַר

Adjectives can be attributive, predictive, or substantive
 * Attributive: modifies a noun.  Attributive adjectives follow the noun they
   modify and agree in gender, number, and definiteness.

Adjectives can be attributive, predictive, or substantive
 * Predicative: asserts something about the noun, e.g. the book is big.
   No verb is used.  Predicative adjectives agree with the noun in gender and number
   but not definiteness.  They may proceed or follow the noun.

Adjectives can be attributive, predictive, or substantive
 * Substantive: no noun present, stands for those who have the trait (e.g. the wise)

Demonstratives as adjectives and pronouns
 * When a demonstrative is functioning as an adjective, it will follow the noun
   it modifies and agree in gender, number, and definiteness. האיש הזה
   * Attributive adjective (if present) will be between the noun and the following
     demonstrative: האיש הטוב הזה

Demonstratives as adjectives and pronouns
 * When a demonstrative is functioning as a pronoun, it will precede the noun and
   agree in gender and number but not definiteness. זה האיש
   * Attributive adjective (if present) will still follow the noun: זה האיש הטוב

Spelling for interrogative particle הֲ
 * Prefixed to a guttural consonant or any consonant with a shewa: הַ

Spelling for interrogative particle הֲ
 * Prefixed to a guttural consonant followed by a qamets: הֶ

Disambiguating the definite article and the interrogative particle
 * The interrogative particle does not usually have a dagesh forte in the next consonant

Disambiguating the definite article and the interrogative particle
 * The interrogative particle is often attached to a verb or another particle

Disambiguating the definite article and the interrogative particle
 * The definite article is never spelled with a hateph patach

Pronominal suffixes
 * When attached to a noun they indicate possessive.

Pronominal suffixes
 * When attached to a preposition or the definite direct object marker they are objective.

Pronominal suffixes
 * Come in types 1 and 2:
   * Type 1 is used with singular nouns, some prepositions, and the direct object marker.
   * Type 2 is used with plural nouns and some prepositions.

Spelling changes for pronominal suffixes
 * Singular nouns can take plural pronominal suffixes (e.g. my horses) and vice versa.

Spelling changes for pronominal suffixes
 * When attached to masculine (or feminine endingless) plural nouns, the ים is dropped

Spelling changes for pronominal suffixes
 * Nouns ending segol ה (e.g. שָׂדֶה ) will drop the segol ה before adding the
   pronominal suffix: שׂדִי my field

Spelling changes for pronominal suffixes
 * Feminine singular nouns ending in patach ה the ה changes to ת before the ending
   is applied.

Spelling changes for pronominal suffixes
 * Many monosyllabic nouns add י to their stem before a pronominal suffix.  Can be
   distinguished in the singular (type 1) by the hireq before the י

Spelling changes for pronominal suffixes
 * The preposition כְּ changes to כָּמוֹ in singular and first person plural when
   taking a pronominal suffix.

Spelling changes for pronominal suffixes
 * The preposition מִן changes to מִמֶ in singular and first person plural when
   taking a pronominal suffix.

Distinguishing similar words with pronominal suffixes
 * Direct object marker and אֵת/אֶת are the same alone but differ with pronominal
   suffix.  Direct object marker has a holem: אֹתֵי while the preposition has hireq
   and dagesh forte: אִתִּי

Distinguishing similar words with pronominal suffixes
 * Preposition עִם and noun עַם both keep their first vowels throughout, both add
   dagesh forte in mem.

Construct chains
 * Roughly equivalent to Greek genitive case.

Construct chains
 * Last noun in the chain is in an absolute state, all others are in construct state.

Construct chains
 * No other words can come between the nouns in a construct chain.

Construct chains
 * A construct chain is either entirely definite or entirely indefinite.  When
   definite only the absolute noun takes the definite article or has a
   pronominal suffix or is a proper noun.

Construct chains
 * Adjectives that modify any noun in the chain come after the chain.  Number and
   gender of the adjective can sometimes determine which noun it modifies, sometimes
   you must use context.  This applies to demonstratives adjectives (this, that) as well.

Construct chains
 * Substantive adjectives functioning as a noun can form part of the construct chain.

Construct chains
 * Inseparable prepositions can be attached to construct nouns.

Construct chains
 * A noun can be made superlative by placing it in a construct chain
   with the construct noun singular and the absolute noun plural and definite:
   e.g. קֹדֶשׁ הַקֱּדָשִׁים the holy of holies, or the most holy [place].

Spelling in construct state
 * A construct noun surrenders its primary accent.  A construct chain is pronounced
   as a single word, with the accent on the absolute noun.  This is sometimes
   marked with a maqqef (-).

Spelling in construct state
 * Masculine plural and both dual endings change to ֵי  e.g. אֱלֹהִים changes to אֱלֹהֵי

Spelling in construct state
 * Vowel reduction:
   * Qamets (and sometimes tsere) change to patach in a final closed syllable:
     e.g. מִשְׁפָּט changes to מִשְׁפַּט
   * Qamets or tsere change to vocal shewa in open, unaccented syllable:
     (or a hateph vowel under a gutteral): נָבִִיא changes to נְבִיא 
 * Feminine singular nouns ending in ָה changes to ַת 
   e.g. תּוֹרָה becomes תּוֹרַת

Spelling in construct state
 * Some monosyllabic nouns add a hireq yod in the contruct state.

Cardinal numbers
 * 'one' acts as an adjective and comes after the noun and agrees in gender and
   definiteness.  Can be used in a construct in which case it means 'one of'.

Cardinal numbers
 * 'two' is a noun, agrees in gender with the modified noun, and can be used in
   absolute or construct state with no change in meaning.

Cardinal numbers
 * 3-10 are nouns but take opposite gender from what they are modifying.  Can also
   be absolute or construct.

Cardinal numbers
 * 2-10 can have a pronominal suffix, meaning 'x of y', e.g. שְׁנֵיהֶם 'two of them'

Cardinal numbers
 * 11-19: x 10, e.g. אַחַתּי עָשָׂר is 11

Cardinal numbers
 * 11-19: 10 agrees with modified noun in gender, while other number is opposite.

Cardinal numbers
 * 20: Masculine plural of 10

Cardinal numbers
 * 30-90: Masculine plural of 3-9

Greek.rule:
Noun rules
2. Every neuter word has the same form in the nominative and accusative.
Noun rules

Noun rules
3. Almost all neuter words end in α in the nominative and accusative plural.

Noun rules
4. In the dative singular, the ι subscripts if possible.

Noun rules
5. Vowels often change their length ('ablaut’).

Noun rules
6. In the genitive and dative, the masculine and neuter will always be identical.

Noun rules
7. Square of stops
  Labial           Unvoiced π  Voiced β  Aspirates φ  Labial + σ = ψ
  Velar (Palatals) Unvoiced κ  Voiced γ  Aspirates χ  Velar + σ = ξ
  Dental           Unvoiced τ  Voiced δ  Aspirates θ  Dental + σ = σ

Noun rules
8. A tau cannot stand at the end of the word and will drop off

Uses of Genitive 
descriptive: Let us put on the armor of light ενδυσμεθα τα οπλα του φωτος

Uses of Genitive 
possessive

Uses of Genitive 
showing apposition to the head noun: You will receive the gift, the Holy Spirit
  λημψεσθε την δωρεαν του αγιου πνευματος

Uses of Genitive 
showing separation from the head noun: being alienated from the commonwealth of
   Israel απελλοτριωμενοι της πολιτειας του Ισραηλ

Uses of Genitive 
subjective, expanding on the idea of the head noun: Who will separate us from
   Christ’s love τισ ημας χωρισει απο της αγαπης του Χπριστου

Uses of Genitive 
objective, receiving the action of the head noun: The blasphemy against the
   Spirit will not be forgiven η του πνευματος βλασφημια ουκ αφεθησεται

Uses of Genitive 
plenary, being both subjective and objective: For the love of Christ compels us
   η γαρ αγαπη του Χριστου συνεχει ημας

Uses of Genitive 
 * relationship: Simon, son of John Σιμων Ιωαννου

Uses of Genitive 
 * partitive, where the subject is a part of the whole, which is genitive: some of
   the branches τινες των κλαδων

Uses of Dative 1/3
Dative Proper (‘to’)

Uses of Dative 1/3
indirect object: He has given him authority to execute judgment εξουσιαν εδωκεν
   αυτῳ κρισιν ποιεν

Uses of Dative 1/3
dative of interest, expression “for”:  Your wife Elizabeth will bear a son for
   you η γυνη σου Ελισαβετ γεννησει υιον σοι (called the “dative of advantage” when
   the idea is to the subject’s advantage and “dative of disadvantage” when the idea
   is not to the subject’s advantage)

Uses of Dative 1/3
reference or respect (English, with respect to): Consider yourselves dead to sin
   λογιζεσθε εαυτους ειναι νεκρους τῃ αμαρτιᾳ

Uses of Dative 1/3
Locative (‘in’, ‘with’)

Uses of Dative 1/3
sphere or realm in which something occurs: Blessed are the pure in heart μακαριοι
   οι καθαροι τῃ καρδιᾳ

Uses of Dative 1/3
A time designation in the dative specifies when something occurs: On the third
   day he will be raised τῃ τριτῃ ημερα εγερθησεται

Uses of Dative 1/3
Association, indicating “with”: Do not be unequally yoked with unbelievers μη
   γινεσθε ετεροζυγουντες απιστοις

Uses of Dative 1/3
Instrumental (‘by’)

Uses of Dative 1/3
The manner in which something is done: He speaks boldly παρρησιᾳ λαλει

Uses of Dative 1/3
The means or instrument by which an action is accomplished:  For it is by grace
    you have been saved Τῃ γαρ χαριτι εστε σεσωσμενοι

Adjectives
Adjectives can be attributive, substantival, or predicative

Adjectives
Attributive - gives a quality or attribute to the word it modifies: ο αγαθος
   λογος εστιν - in this situation adjective agrees with word it modifies in case,
   number, and gender.

Adjectives
Substantival - when an adjective functions as a noun: ο αγαθος εστιν “the good
   (person) is” - in this situation case is determined by its function (subject,
   object, etc.) its gender and number by what it stands for.

Adjectives
Predicate - asserts (predicates) something about the subject. ο ανθρωπος αγαθος
   verb ειμι may be implied

Adjectives
If there is an article immediately before the adjective, it is either attributive
   (if there is a noun to modify) or substantival.  In attributive case, adjective
   may be before or after the noun: ο αγαθος ανθρωπος or ο ανθρωπος ο αγαθος
  (Exception:  demonstrative pronouns are attributive without the article: ουτος ὁ ἀνθρωπος "this man")

Adjectives
If the noun has an article and the adjective does not (called anarthrous) then
   the adjective is functioning as a predicate: ο ανθρωπος αγαθος

Adjectives
When there is no article context is your only guide.

Adjective Declensions
2-1-2:  masculine and neuter in 2nd, feminine in 1st

Adjective Declensions
3-1-3:  masculine and neuter in 3rd, feminine in 1st

Adjective Declensions
2-2:    all in 2nd (masculine and feminine have same endings)

Adjective Declensions
2-2 are listed in the lexicon with just 2nd declension masculine and neuter endings.

Adjective Declensions
3-3:    all in 3rd (masculine and feminine have same endings)

Degrees of an adjective
Positive: uncompared e.g μεγας large

Degrees of an adjective
Comparative: greater of two items: e.g. μειζων larger

Degrees of an adjective
Superlative: greatest, or comparison of 3 or more e.g. μεγιστος largest
    where English would expect a superlative

Neuter Plural Subjects
Greek normally uses a singular verb when the subject is neuter plural.  Indicates
the writer is viewing the subject as a group rather than as individuals.  In English
this will require a plural verb:
  δοκιμαζετε τα πνευματα ει εκ του θεου εστιν
  Test the spirits and see if they are from God.

Uses of article 
Definite article

Uses of article 
Attaching adjective to preceding noun μετα των αγγελων των αγιων

Uses of article 
Is often used with proper names and other nouns that English would not use it with

Uses of article 
Can be used with participle or adjective to make it into a noun.

Uses of article 
Is sometimes omitted when English would use it: Εν αρχη ην ο λογος

Uses of article 
Can function as a personal or possessive pronoun: Οι δε ειπαν προς αυτον And they said to him

Uses of article 
Can govern two nouns together, linking them:
    προσδεχομενοι την μακαριαν ελπιδα και επιφανειαν της δοξης του μεγαλου θεου και
      σωτηρος ημων Ιησου Χριστου

Uses of article 
    waiting for our blessed hope, the appearing of the glory of our great God and
      Savior Jesus Christ.

The function of the article in Greek is not to make something definite, 

Rather its presence emphasizes identity.

The function of the article in Greek is not to make something definite, 

anaphoric: where the article refers back to a previous reference:
   κήρυξον τὸν λόγον preach the word (referring back to discussion in 2 Tim 3

The function of the article in Greek is not to make something definite, 

deictic: the article points out someone or something present and often is best translated as a demonstrative:
   προσῆλθον αὐτῷ οἱ μαθηταί λὲγοντες ἔρημός ἐστιν _ὁ_ τόπος The disciples came to him and said, '_This_ place is desolate'

The function of the article in Greek is not to make something definite, 

par excellence: the article identifies a substantive as in a class by itself:
   ὁ προφήτης εἶ σύ; Are you the Prophet?

The function of the article in Greek is not to make something definite, 

monadic:  the article identifies a substantive as unique:
   ἴδε ὁ ἀμνος τοῦ θεοῦ Behold, the lamb of God

The function of the article in Greek is not to make something definite, 

can turn a participle or adjective into a noun
   Πᾶς _ὁ γεγεννημένος_ ἐκ τοῦ θεοῦ Everyone _who has been born of God_

The function of the article in Greek is not to make something definite, 

can function as a personal, possessive, or relative pronoun
   Οἱ δὲ εἶπαν πρὸς αὐτόν And they said to him
   Οἱ ἄνδρες, ἀγαπᾶτε _τὰς_ γυναῖκας Husbands, love _your_ wives

The function of the article in Greek is not to make something definite, 

can function as a grammatical marker:  μετά τῶν ἀγγελων _τῶν_ ἁγίων with the holy angels

The function of the article in Greek is not to make something definite, 

When the article is not present, it is generally emphasizing the quality of the substantive:
   ὁ θεὸς ἀγάπη ἐστίν God is love (focusing not on that God loves, but that he is the very essence of love

The function of the article in Greek is not to make something definite, 

also not used when the substantive is not specific

Articles can proceed prepositional phrases
Usually turning them into relative clauses:
     τους παιδας τους εν βηθλεεμ
     The children who are in Bethlehem

Articles can proceed prepositional phrases
Sometimes turning it into a substantive: 
     ελαλησαν τον λογον του κυριου πασιν τοις εν τῃ οικιᾳ
     They spoke the word of the Lord to all who were in the house

Three Uses of αὐτος 
 1. Personal pronoun.

Three Uses of αὐτος 
 2. Adjectival intensive.  This is used to modify another word and is placed in the
    predicate position.  This is usually translated into English with a reflexive
    pronoun: αὐτος ὁ ἀποστολος the apostle himself.  When functioning as an intensive,
    αὐτος is usually in the nominative case and modifies the subject.

Three Uses of αὐτος 
 3. Identical adjective, meaning “the same”.  Usually in the attributive position.
    και παλιν απελθων προσηυξατο τον αυτον λογον

Three Uses of αὐτος 
    And again after going away he prayed the same word.

The demonstratives οὑτος and ἐκεινος can be used as pronouns or
adjectives.  Can also be used as a personal pronoun at times.

ἀν used in conjunction with a relative pronoun makes it indefinite
e.g. ὅς who ὅς ἀν whoever

Attraction: Occasionally the case of the relative pronoun is determined
not by its function in the relative clause but by its antecedent.  This usually
happens when it is in the immediate proximity of its antecedent, when the
antecedent is dative or genitive and the relative pronoun normally would be
accusative.

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * two like vowels combine to the associated long vowel

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * two like vowels combine to the associated long vowel except
   * ο + ο = ου
   * ε + ε = ει

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * (anything but ε) + ο = ω (commutative)

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * ε + ο = ου (commutative)

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * anything + ω = ω (commutative)

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * α + ε/η = α

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * ε/η + α  = η

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * α + ε + ι = ᾳ

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * ε + α + ι = ῃ

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * ο + ε + ι = οι

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * Dipthongs:  if the contract vowel and the first vowel of the dipthong are the
   same, they combine to a single instance of the vowel.  Otherwise they contract.
   If the second vowel of the dipthong is a ι it subscripts if possible.

A deponent verb is one that is middle or passive in form but active
in meaning.  It does not take a middle or passive meaning.
Verbs can be deponent in one tense but not in another (e.g. ἔρχομαι is deponent in
the present but not in the aorist.)
75% of middle forms in the NT are deponent.

Separating γινομαι, γενναω and γινωσκω:
 * γινομαι will always have a vowel between the γ and the ν.  Usually an ε.
 * γενναω always has double ν and is completely regular.
 * γινωσκω, except in the present tense, does not have a vowel between the γ and the ν.

Verb roots and stems
Pattern 1: root not modified.  Example: *ἀκου

Verb roots and stems
Pattern 2: different roots in different stems

Verb roots and stems
Verbs that have second aorists are normally verbs that alter their
     root in the formation of their present tense stem.

Verb roots and stems
Pattern 3: verbs with roots ending in a liquid (λ, μ, ν, ρ)
